title.value: Functional Status Assessments and Target Setting for Patients with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

text.value: Percentage of patients 18 years of age and older with a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for whom a score from one of a select list of validated functional status assessment (FSA) tools was recorded at least twice during the measurement period and for whom a care target was documented and linked to the initial assessment.

value.value:

Due to technical limitations, registered trademarks are indicated by (R) or [R] and unregistered trademarks are indicated by (TM) or [TM].

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is the fourth leading cause of death in the United States (CDC 2011) and costs an estimated $49.9 billion a year (NHLBI 2009); this equates to approximately $6000 per patient annually in health care related cost (Miller et al. 2005). Approximately 15 million people have COPD and another estimated 12 million remain undiagnosed (NHLBI 2012). COPD exacerbations not only account for the majority of economic burden that this disease has on the health system, but also lead to significant impairment of quality of life (Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease [GOLD] 2014). Currently, the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends the use of spirometry to diagnose COPD (USPSTF 2008), but this and other physiological measures typically used for COPD do not evaluate health-related quality of life. Quality of life must be regularly assessed for patients with COPD because their perceived functional status affects their ability to engage in self-management, which has been shown to reduce hospital admissions (Effing et al. 2007). Because quality of life instruments can yield information concerning disease stage and severity as well as predict outcomes, combining the current recommendation of physiological measures with quality of life measures could increase the detection of clinically meaningful improvement in a patient's disease status (Singer and Yusen 2012). Thus, more effective self-management and involvement in care through use of functional status assessments and target-setting may lead to improved outcomes and fewer avoidable or preventable complications.

COPD assessment is recommended to determine the severity of the disease, its impact on the patient's health status, and the risk of future events (such as exacerbations, hospital admissions, or death). These determinations are crucial to guide therapeutic decision making.
A comprehensive symptom assessment using tools such as COPD Assessment Test (CAT) and COPD Control Questionnaire (CCQ) are suitable for these purposes (GOLD 2014).
A higher rate indicates better quality
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). "Compressed Mortality Database", 2011. Available at http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/products/pubs/pubd/series/ser.htm. Accessed December 28, 2012.

National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute. "Morbidity & Mortality: 2009 Chart Book on Cardiovascular, Lung, and Blood Diseases." Bethesda, Maryland: US Department of Health and Human Services, Public Health Service, National Institutes of Health, 2009. Available at http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/resources/docs/2009_ChartBook.pdf. Accessed May 14, 2013.
Miller, J.D., T. Foster, et al. "Direct Costs of COPD in the U.S.: An Analysis of Medical Expenditure Panel Survey (MEPS) data." COPD, vol. 2, no. 3, 2005, pp. 311-318.

National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute. "Morbidity & Mortality: 2012 Chart Book on Cardiovascular, Lung, and Blood Diseases." Bethesda, Maryland: US Department of Health and Human Services, Public Health Service, National Institutes of Health, 2012. Available at http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/resources/docs/cht-book.htm. Accessed May 14, 2013.
Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD). "Global Strategy for the Diagnosis, Management, and Prevention of COPD", 2014. Available at www.goldcopd.com. Accessed May 7, 2014.

United States Preventive Service Task Force (USPSTF). "Screening for Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease Using Spirometry", 2008. Available at http://www.uspreventiveservicestaskforce.org/. Accessed May 13, 2013.

Effing T., E. Monninkhof, P.D. van der Valk, J. van der Palen et al. "Self-Management Education for Patients with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease." Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, issue 1, 2007, CD002990.

Singer J.P., and R.D. Yusen. "Defining Patient-Reported Outcomes in Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease: The Patient-Centered Experience." Medical Clinics of North America. vol. 96, no. 4, 2012, pp. 767-87.

Functional Status Assessment (FSA): A functional status assessment is used to determine whether the goals of therapy are being met. Constructs of functional status include: 1. Functional capacity - "One's maximum potential to perform activities" 2. Functional performance - The physical, psychological, social, occupational, and spiritual activities people actually do in the normal course of their lives to meet basic needs 3. Functional reserve - The difference between capacity and performance 4. Capacity utilization - The effort used to reach the functional performance
Index FSA Score: The first functional status assessment (FSA) score recorded in the patient record during the measurement period. The Index FSA does not need to occur during an in-person encounter to be considered valid; it can occur in the 14 days prior to an in-person encounter.

- Patients must have completed either the Dartmouth Cooperative Functional Assessment Charts (COOP) or the PROMIS Global Health Scale (PROMIS-10). - The FSA score documented in the electronic health record must be the total score. - The Index FSA Score must be linked to an encounter (the FSA visit). Completion of the FSA can occur during the encounter or within 14 days prior to it. - A quantitative target based on the FSA (either total or item-level score) must be set and documented during or up to 72 hours following the initial FSA-related encounter. - Any member of the care team (e.g. physician, nurse, nurse practitioner, physicianâ€™s assistant, care manager etc.) may set a target with the patient. - Patients must also complete a second FSA using the same tool as the Index FSA at least 90 days after the Index FSA.
Patients 18 years of age and older with COPD and an encounter during the measurement period
Patients in the Initial Population who have their first encounter within the first 260 days of the measurement period

Patients for whom a score from one of a select list of functional status assessment (FSA) tools was recorded at least twice and for whom a care target was documented and linked to the initial assessment
Not Applicable
Not applicable
Not applicable
Not applicable
For every patient evaluated by this measure also identify payer, race, ethnicity and sex.
